awd_abstract_narration:
Since the seminal work of Shannon in 1949 cryptography has been founded on unproven computational complexity. The security of cryptographic systems could fall apart if the assumptions behind their design turn out to be false. Thus, it is crucial to base the security of crypto-systems on weakest possible assumptions. A main component of finding minimal assumptions is to ``separate'' cryptographic tasks from assumptions that are weaker than those used in constructions. In light of recent developments in cryptography, the following two directions will be pursued:

New Techniques: A formal model to abstract the properties of cryptographic proofs and techniques is necessary to prove separations. Previously studied models, however, do not consider some of the most useful recent techniques in cryptography and mainly focus on uniform, black-box, and classical (non-quantum) proof techniques. A major goal of this project is to develop new foundations to model these new cryptographic techniques.

New Tasks and Assumptions: Recently cryptography has gone through a revolution of exploring feasibility of highly structured crypto tasks, even if this comes at the cost of using newly introduced assumptions. The second major goal of this project is to deepen our understanding of the assumptions necessary for achieving these tasks. A closely related goal is to identify the relative power of these new tasks among themselves.

To disseminate the above ideas and achieve broader impact, the project will include educational activities such as: course development, outreach to high school students to motivate them pursue degrees in theoretical computer science and cryptography, and mentoring graduate as well as undergraduate students.

por.por_cntn:
Cryptography is the science of designing “secure” mathematical algorithms that protect privacy and confidentiality of data/users in computation and communication. The state of affairs in cryptography is far from satisfactory: our ability to design truly secure solution is pending on resolving deep mathematical questions that have remained open even after decades of research. As a result, modern cryptography is based on mathematical *assumptions* that are widely believed to be true, or at least no one seems able to refute them. Examples include the assumption about the existence of so-called one-way functions, that are functions that are easy to compute and yet computationally hard to invert.

The core goal and outcome of this project was to identify *barriers* that exist against achieving secure cryptographic solutions and protocols. A primary goal was to identify barriers against basing cryptographic protocols on the *weaker* (and hence the better) type of assumptions, in order to have more confidence in the designed solution. The focus of the project was on recent modern tasks in cryptography that are, so far, based on less standard and less studied mathematical conjectures. The most prominent example of such task that was intensely studied in this project is the task of “code obfuscation”. In obfuscation, the goal is to obfuscate a program’s code so that: (1) everyone can run it, (2) no-one can understand anything from the obfuscated code more than, say, running it on arbitrary inputs. Obfuscation is known to have tens of applications in foundations of cryptography, and hence it is considered one of the holy grails in this area. One of the themes of the outcome of this project was to prove barriers that exist on basing the task of obfuscation on “standard” cryptographic assumptions that has led to private-key cryptography, or even public-key cryptography. It was shown through a series of papers (co-authored with PI’s PhD students and colleages) that code obfuscation is of a fundamentally harder level, when it comes to constructing it from previously used assumptions.

A tightly related goal of this project was to model new techniques that are also widely used in cryptography in order to prove the limit of their power. Older cryptographic toolkits mostly used so-called "black-box" methods that use one cryptographic task as a subroutine and build more complex systems without relying on the details of how the sub-system is implemented. Doing so is also common-practice in software development. However, modern cryptographic methods go beyond this basic setting and employ "non-black-box" techniques as well. A major focus of this project was to model non-black-box techniques in a way that one can also investigate their limitations. This was exactly done in a series of papers co-authored with colleagues and PI’s PhD student and specific examples of results were proved for limitations of non-black-box techniques for realizing code obfuscation, but the framework is more general and applicable in broader settings.

Finally, the project has outcomes that exceeded the original vision. In particular, surprising connections were established between limits of cryptographic power and the active area of "adversarially robust machine learning". In robust machine learning, one tries to design learning algorithms that are robust to adversarial tampering that might happen during the training or testing phase of the process. It was shown through a series of papers that limits of "coin-flipping" protocols in cryptography imply barriers for adversarially robust learning methods. A coin-flipping protocol is a cryptographic algorithm involving multiple parties who share public messages with each other with the goal of agreeing on a random bit. The output bit should be random even if some of the participating parties deviate from the protocol. Doing so is a building block in many other cryptographic tasks and protocols. Our results showed that understanding the limits of cryptographic goals and tools would be important also for understanding basic questions in other areas such as learning theory.

Student support: With the valuable help of this grant, the PI supported the research of 3 PhD students and one postdoctoral researcher.

Publications: With the help of this grant, the PI published 17 peer reviewed conference papers in cryptography and Theoretical Computer Science conferences as well as 2 journal articles.

Teaching: During the course of this grant, and based on the goals depicted for this proposal dealing with foundations of cryptography, the PI developed and taught new cryptography courses both at the undergraduate [Fall 2016] and graduate levels [Fall 2014] as well as an intermediate level course suitable for both levels [Spring 2018 and Spring 2015]. The material for these courses, including lecture notes, are accessible from the PI’s homepage.
